options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We watched pre-recorded content as well.
Listening - youtube links to songs to listen to

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: To be honest I didn't learn that much about writing lyrics. Most of the classes were just presentations by guest lecturers or workshops with students' pieces, and Professor Korie didn't spend much time actually teaching per se. I can't really remember any specific techniques that he named, and lyric writing seems just as difficult and mysterious as it did before I took the class.
I developed knowledge about the genres of musical theatre and opera, types of songs found in each genre, and how to write effective lyrics for each genre.
I learned a lot about the principles of musical theater lyric writing and about the different classes / genres of musical theater songs.
How to write lyrics for anything dramatic. You learn to think and write like a dramatist.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Korie treated students differently based on whether they were theater/music majors or not. He gave the "serious" writers a lot more screentime. A more specific curriculum would also have been nice. The guests were interesting, but they took up too much time that we could have spent learning lyric writing techniques.

I thought this course was excellent. One stand-out strength is the real-world nature of it, especially having guest specialists attend our classes and give live feedback. 

We did an overview of the genres of musical theatre and opera in class, and were assigned listening from both genres for homework, but I still feel I am a little lacking in broader knowledge about each genre. There are many musicals and operas I haven't seen and don't know anything about. Maybe one way to address this would be to have a shortlist of say 20 of the most "must-watch" from each genre, and have the students pick one, watch it in full, summarise it and present back to the class the next week? That way we could all learn the key plot and numbers from the major musicals in a high-speed way, from each other.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Despite everything being over Zoom, we still had to do a collaboration project with a student composer at the end of the semester that was more or less impossible to do well.

I thought the pandemic-related learning challenges were handled very well and Michael and his team did a great job of navigating zoom and making performances and guest appearances happen. I can't think of any way this could be improved!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! I learned a great deal and very much enjoyed the class.

I would recommend this course to another student. Professor Korie was great and always provided helpful feedback. The discussions were really interesting, and it was fun to share work and hear the work of other students.

Absolutely! This is a fun and relatively low stress course that absolutely improves your dramatic writing and sense of lyrics. You won't listen to shows the same way, you'll gain an appreciation for OPERA of all things. Professor Korie brings in a bunch of really great guest teachers that are wonderful and giving.
